instruction: My favorite witty review of The Rings of Power series is this:
output:
"What a disappointment! I was expecting The Lord of the Rings, but instead got The Lords of the Rings. It's like they took all the best parts out and replaced them with boring political intrigue and pointless subplots."

I feel this way because I am a fan of Tolkien's works, and after watching the first two episodes of the series, I was hoping for an adaption that would be true to the spirit of the books. Instead, we get a very watered down version of what makes Tolkien's world so great, with characters that are barely recognizable from their source material, and a plot that feels like it's just going through the motions.

But perhaps this is the point. Maybe the showrunners realize that people like me are looking for a faithful adaption, and so they're trying to subvert our expectations by creating something that is not only different from the books, but also (in my opinion) inferior to them.

If this is the case, then I have to ask: Why? Why create a new work that is so obviously inferior to its source material? Why not just make a completely new fantasy series, one that is unencumbered by the expectations of fans like me?

Maybe the answer lies in the fact that there is no such thing as a fresh idea anymore. Everything has been done before, and we know it. So when a new work comes along that tries to rehash something that's already been done, we can't help but compare it to the original. And if it falls short, we're bound to be disappointed.
So maybe the real question here is: How do we move beyond this cycle of derivative works, where everything is just a rehash of something else? How do we create truly new and innovative stories that capture our imagin

instruction: Discover the most relevant StackOverflow questions for your search term. And output a list of their URLs.
input: remove item in array
output:
python
How to remove an element from an array in Python? (1) In the first approach, we are using slice notation to remove an element from the list. Here, we are removing the first item from our list []. 
# print_list([1, 2, 3]) # [1, 2, 3] # print_list([1, 2, 3]).remove(1) # [2, 3]
In the second approach, we are using the .pop() method to remove an element from the list. Here, we are removing the first item from our list []. 
# print_list([1, 2, 3]) # [1, 2, 3] # print_list([1, 2, 3]).pop(0) # []
In the third approach, we are using the .remove() method to remove an element from the list. Here, we are removing the first item from our list []. 
# print_list([1, 2, 3]) # [1, 2, 3] # print_list([1, 2, 3]).remove(1) # []

instruction: Design a soothing pastel color palette for your slides. Pastel colors generally come across as pretty and delicate, so you’ll want to make sure your presentation calls for a similar mood. Choose up to five colors or color codes.
output:
It’s a great idea to get some feedback on your work from people you trust. This will help you keep focused on your goals and make sure that your work is on track. When you ask others for feedback, be specific about what you would like them to comment on. For example, you might ask “Does this presentation communicate the main points I want it to?” or, “Is there anything in this section that seems confusing or unclear?” Asking a question like this invites your friend or colleague to offer genuine advice rather than just praise or criticism.
Of course, slides should always have text on them, but too much text can overwhelm viewers. Use bullet points to break up long text into more manageable chunks, and be selective about which details are most important to include. Viewers should be able to get a general sense of your message just by looking at your slides, so you don’t need to include every detail. Use any extra details as supporting material in your speaker notes or handout.
A traditional background design often includes a solid color for the background and white lettering. However, there are many other options available. You may want to incorporate an image or pattern into your slides to enhance the overall look. Consider using a different color background for each slide in the presentation, or simply use a pattern or image to add visual interest while still maintaining a consistent theme.

instruction: Write a step-by-step guide for resolving GitHub merge conflicts.
output:
Update: This post is now out of date. Please see GitHub's documentation on resolving merge conflicts instead.
I struggled a lot with merge conflicts in GitHub, and finally I found the best way to resolve them. These are not in any particular order.
You have two branches. One is your local branch (let's say, "develop") and another is a remote branch ("remotes/origin/develop"). Open these two branches in your editor or IDE. Now make sure both are identical. For example, if your local branch is at line 400 and remote branch is at line 399, add one more line in your local branch and push it to the remote branch.
This command will create a new local branch called "merged" which should be identical to both "remotes/origin/develop" and "your-local-branch". In my case, my local branch was "develop" so command would be:
$ git checkout -b merged remotes/origin/develop develop
Now you can commit and push your changes to the "merged" local branch.
If your local branch is already up-to-date with the remote branch (i.e., you didn't make any changes locally), you don't have to do anything. Just type:
$ git checkout merged
and you are done. You can now merge your local branch into the remote branch.
Your local branch is now ready to be merged into the remote branch.
Let's assume you want to merge "develop" into "master". Switch to "develop" branch and run the following commands.
$ git checkout master
$ git merge develop
In GitHub, when you try to merge a branch, it gives you two options - edit the diff and then merge or skip the editing and merge anyway. If you have a lot of conflicts, choose the first option and solve all the conflicts. Once you

instruction:
One or more jobs can be run automatically by a workflow. The workflows are defined in the repository as YAML files and will run if an event occurs in the repository, as well as manually, or on a certain schedule.
Bring an example of a workflow that demonstrate the CI/CD features of GitHub Actions.
output:
A simple example of a workflow that demonstrates the CI/CD features of GitHub Actions is a Python project that uses pip to install dependencies and then runs a unit test suite. The workflow consists of two jobs: "ci" and "cd".
The "ci" job is triggered by a push to the main branch or by pulling a pull request. It checks out the code, runs pip to install the dependencies, and then runs the unit tests with the command "pytest". If the tests pass, the job succeeds and the code is merged into the main branch or the pull request is merged.
The "cd" job is triggered on each push to the main branch or pull request. It runs the command "pip freeze > requirements.txt" to generate a requirements file for the project, which can be used to easily install the dependencies in other environments.
By using GitHub Actions, this Python project can automatically build and test its code, and deploy it to another environment with just a few clicks. This saves time and ensures that the code is always up-to-date and working correctly.

instruction: You are given some reviews for a movie. Each video might have mentioned some negative or positive points about the movie. Read them carefully and extract the positive and negative points mentioned in all of the reviews. Then, make a list of these points and summarize them as positive points and negative points.
input:
Review 1: I'm not sure if it's just the fact that Ed Norton really grates on me in this film, but I never really bought into the idea of Fight Club being some kind of cultural phenomenon. Yes it's an innovative story, told via a strong script, engaging characters and intense cinematography. But is it really worthy of such high praise? Personally, I find it starts to fall apart halfway through and actually becomes quite tedious towards the end. Everything just becomes a little bit childish and contrived as the story loses touch with its base elements and the rage against the machine vibe takes over. I have huge respect for the way this film was made but, much like The Matrix, I feel like people attach way more importance to this movie than it deserves.
Review 2: The film tells the story of men who cannot adapt to the social order in today's world, under the leadership of Tyler Durden, to discover their natural instinct, masculinity, and to escape from their unhappy lives.
Review 3: Despite a good theme, great acting and important messages that this movie convey in an unorthodox way, I think it fails to connect the audience with the storyline and leaves him in a world of confusion. Although, majority of reviews find this movie entertaining and interesting, yet I would choose to be a minority that believes that this movie is extremely overrated.
Review 4: Is creating chaos, explosions and membership in a militant sect the way to get rid of material shackles ?! The visual effects are fascinating and the story is compelling until the second half. Unfortunately, it doesn't end well.

instruction: Provide a Java solution to the following problem.
input:
Given an integer n, return true if it is a power of three. Otherwise, return false.
An integer n is a power of three, if there exists an integer x such that n == 3^x.

Example 1:
In: n = 27
Out: true
Explanation: 27 = 3^3

Example 2:
In: n = 0
Out: false
Explanation: There is no x where 3^x = 0.

Example 3:
In: n = -1
Out: false
Explanation: There is no x where 3x = (-1).
 
Constraints:
-231 <= n <= 231 - 1
Follow up: Could you solve it without loops/recursion?

instruction: Summarize the article you have been given in a brief manner.
input:
Mathematics and art are related in a variety of ways. Mathematics has itself been described as an art motivated by beauty. Mathematics can be discerned in arts such as music, dance, painting, architecture, sculpture, and textiles. This article focuses, however, on mathematics in the visual arts.
Mathematics and art have a long historical relationship. Artists have used mathematics since the 4th century BC when the Greek sculptor Polykleitos wrote his Canon, prescribing proportions conjectured to have been based on the ratio 1:√2 for the ideal male nude. Persistent popular claims have been made for the use of the golden ratio in ancient art and architecture, without reliable evidence. In the Italian Renaissance, Luca Pacioli wrote the influential treatise De divina proportione (1509), illustrated with woodcuts by Leonardo da Vinci, on the use of the golden ratio in art. Another Italian painter, Piero della Francesca, developed Euclid's ideas on perspective in treatises such as De Prospectiva Pingendi, and in his paintings. The engraver Albrecht Dürer made many references to mathematics in his work Melencolia I. In modern times, the graphic artist M. C. Escher made intensive use of tessellation and hyperbolic geometry, with the help of the mathematician H. S. M. Coxeter, while the De Stijl movement led by Theo van Doesburg and Piet Mondrian explicitly embraced geometrical forms. Mathematics has inspired textile arts such as quilting, knitting, cross-stitch, crochet, embroidery, weaving, Turkish and other carpet-making, as well as kilim. In Islamic art, symmetries are evident in forms as varied as Persian girih and Moroccan zellige tilework, Mughal jali pierced stone screens, and widespread muqarnas vaulting.
output:
Mathematics has been used for art in the 20th and 21st centuries, notably by the Russian constructivists and the Polish school of mathematical graphics.
Mathematics also plays a role in the interpretation of visual art, through such topics as fractal analysis, the study of self-similarity in art, and mathematical aesthetics.

instruction: Improve the article using your knowledge of the topic in order to make it more informative.
input: The "fair trade" movement, also known as the "trade justice" movement, promotes the use of labour, environmental and social standards for the production of commodities, particularly those exported from the Third and Second Worlds to the First World. Such ideas have also sparked a debate on whether trade itself should be codified as a human right.
output:
Fair trade has its roots in the anti-slavery movement of the 19th century. Fair trading organizations were set up in Europe and North America to certify that products came from free laborers. The International Fair Trade Association has traced the origins of fair trade to the early Cooperative Wholesale Society founded by Roland Hill in Taplow, England in 1844.[3] In the United States and Canada, organizations such as the Student Christian Movement and the YMCA supported cooperatives in European countries as a way to promote better prices for farmers and workers. The first fair trade store was opened in Harlem, NY in 1968 by Judson Mills, who also worked with the Catholic Worker Movement. During the 1970s and 1980s, fair trade organizations became more widespread, particularly in Europe. In the early 21st century, fair trade became more international in scope, with organizations in Japan, Korea, and other parts of Asia.
The concept of fair trade is based upon the idea of mutually beneficial long-term relationships between producers and consumers, not simply short-term transactions. Additionally, fair trade organizations seek to address the power imbalance between producers and buyers. The goals of fair trade organizations are to: raise the standard of living of producers; eliminate or reduce the exploitation of producers; assist producers in gaining access to markets; ensure that producers receive the revenues necessary to invest in their future; and protect the environment and promote sustainability. Organizations also strive to empower producers through education and training.
There are many organizations dedicated to promoting fair trade. One example is TransFair USA, a nonprofit organization that provides for the certification and promotion of fair trade products. Another example is the Fairtra

instruction: Make the article available in a second language by translating it into it.
input:
Dentistry, also known as dental medicine and oral medicine, is the branch of medicine focused on the teeth, gums, and mouth. It consists of the study, diagnosis, prevention, management, and treatment of diseases, disorders, and conditions of the mouth, most commonly focused on dentition (the development and arrangement of teeth) as well as the oral mucosa. Dentistry may also encompass other aspects of the craniofacial complex including the temporomandibular joint. The practitioner is called a dentist.
Translate to French:
output: Dentistry, also known as dental medicine and oral medicine, is the branch of medicine focused on the teeth, gums, and mouth. It consists of the study, diagnosis, prevention, management, and treatment of diseases, disorders, and conditions of the mouth, most commonly focused on dentition (the development and arrangement of teeth) as well as the oral mucosa. Dentistry may also encompass other aspects of the craniofacial complex including the temporomandibular joint. The practitioner is called a dentist.

instruction: Create a daily itinerary based on the given information.
input: Our family is looking for a 9-day Morocco trip that has light to moderate activity levels.
output:
We are interested in seeing cities, desert landscapes, and the countryside. We are flexible on time of year but would like to avoid the heat of summer. We also have a 15-year old daughter who is interested in history and art, a 13-year old son who is interested in hiking, mountain biking and rock climbing, and a 9-year old who would enjoy seeing animals and nature. We would like help with suggestions for accommodations and activities as well.
I recommend starting your trip in Marrakech and ending it in Fes. You can fly into Marrakech Menara Airport (RAK) and out of Fes Saiss Airport (FEZ). This will allow you to see the highlights of Morocco while keeping your journey to 9 days.
On day 1, explore the Medina of Marrakech with a local guide, visit Bahia Palace, and have dinner at Dar Rouge. Stay overnight at the Riad Fès.
Day 2, go on a guided tour that includes the Majorelle Gardens, Tanners’ Quarter, and the Koutoubia Mosque. Enjoy lunch at La Maison des Spices. In the afternoon, take a cooking class at the Ourika Valley where your family can learn how to make Moroccan tagine. Stay overnight at the Auberge Imlil.
On day 3, hike up to Toubkal, North Africa's highest peak, with a local guide and spend the night in a traditional Berber tent.
Day 4, enjoy breakfast and have a camel ride in the sand dunes of Merzouga. Watch the sunset and spend the night at a hotel in Merzouga.
Day 5, visit the ancient city of Ait Ben

instruction: Give students tips on how to keep their nerves under control during class presentations.
output:
Go to a quiet room, take 5 deep breaths, and repeat a positive affirmation.
Make sure you know your topic inside and out, so that you don’t get nervous when it’s time to present.

Use visual aids such as PowerPoint or whiteboard to help you stay on track.

instruction: Think of an idea to help you win a challenge given to you. Write the steps you need to take to develop the idea as well.
input:
What can you make by recycling and repurposing some old, previously used materials? We want to see it!
Projects must incorporate some kind of used materials - take that old used thing, and turn it into something new and different!
E-waste is a huge problem. What can you make using old electronics and other salvageable electronic materials? 
We have a special judges prize for our favorite Instructable that incorporates or is related to reusing e-waste.
Be smart and be safe; note that potentially deadly projects (like Lichtenberg/fractal wood burning machines) will not be allowed to be published or submitted to this contest.
output: If you have a great idea, but need help developing it, consider joining the Recycling Inventors Group.

instruction: Estimate the cost of supplies required to create the given project and calculate the total cost.
input:
DIY Water Chiller
Required items are: Ice-maker, Icebox/cooler, Temperature regulator, Aquarium pump x2, 12V power supply
output:
, Water pump, Tube fittings, Tank for chilled water, Cooling fans.
Instructions: Connect the water pump to the ice-maker and coolant reservoir. Connect the temperature regulator between the water pump and ice-maker. Run the cold water from the ice-maker into the aquarium pump which in turn will run into a tank filled with water at a lower temperature. This water will be pumped back into the ice-maker as coolant. Connect the second aquarium pump to return the water to its original temperature. Finally, connect the temperature regulator between the second pump and the ice-maker to maintain a constant temperature.

instruction: Develop a mental exercise that can help people manage their anxiety and explain how it works.
output: Mindfulness exercises are a great way to help manage anxiety. An example of a mindfulness exercise is to take a few deep breaths, close your eyes and focus on the present moment. As you breathe in, count to 4 and as you breathe out, count to 6. Repeat this cycle for several minutes. This helps to calm the mind and body, reducing feelings of anxiousness.

instruction: Solve this equation.
output:
First we factor x^3 - 4x^2 + 6x out. We can use the quadratic formula to do this:
(x - (-b ± sqrt(b^2 - 4ac))/2a)^3
where a = 1, b = -4, and c = 6.
Rearranging, we get:
x - (-4 ± sqrt(49))/21 = 0
Simplifying, we get:
x = 1.738 or -3.262
So the roots are approximately 1.738 and -3.262.

instruction: Describe the content of the article in a brief manner.
input: A study published earlier this year by Zee and her team examined the role of light in sleep for healthy adults in their 20s. Sleeping for only one night with a dim light, such as a TV set with the sound off, raised the blood sugar and heart rate of the young people during the sleep lab experiment. An elevated heart rate at night has been shown in prior studies to be a risk factor for future heart disease and early death, while higher blood sugar levels are a sign of insulin resistance, which can ultimately lead to type 2 diabetes.
output:
The researchers also found that when the young adults spent a second night in the lab with the lights dimmed, their bodies adjusted somewhat to the lower light level. The changes in blood sugar and heart rate were reduced compared with the first night. But both remained higher than they were when the participants slept in a well-lit room.
“We know that sleep is so important for health,” Zee said. “This study shows that one aspect of sleep — the light environment — is not benign.”
Ani Manjikiani, an assistant professor of neurology at Brigham and Women’s Hospital and Harvard Medical School who was not involved in the study, called it “very interesting.”
“There are other studies that have looked at sleep and glucose metabolism, but this is the first time I’ve seen them looking at sleep and heart rate variability,” Manjikiani said.
Heart rate variability refers to the variations in the time between each heartbeat. A person’s overall heart rate variability is influenced by factors such as age, physical fitness and emotional state. Higher overall heart rate variability has been associated with better outcomes, including survival after a heart attack and improved cardiovascular health after reperfusion of the heart following a heart attack. Lower heart rate variability has been linked to increased risk of death and heart disease.
“It makes sense physiologically that if you have less variability, your body is not very good at recovering from stressors,” Manjikiani said.
Zee said she thinks the results could extend to all types of light — not just the light produced by TV sets and computer screens. And the findings likely apply equally to children and older adults, she said.
“Light at night can disrupt circadian rhythms, which are important across the life

instruction: On the basis of the subject of the email, determine whether the email should be treated as spam or not.
input: Dermatologists don't like her!
output:
Oh horrors!
Dermatologists don't like her! Oh horrors!
I was a little surprised when I read this e-mail, and then I figured out why... because of the way that it is written. If it were me, I would have written it more like this: "I went to see a dermatologist about some skin problems, and she told me that all my products were crap." This makes it sound like you went in specifically to ask for an opinion about your skincare products, rather than going in for a general check-up, which is what it sounds like they are referencing.
This is obviously not spam. Do with this information as you will.

instruction: Extract the method that has been used in the research from the abstract of the paper. Give the exact sentences from the abstract that discuss the method.
input: We present a state-of-the-art speech recognition system developed using end-to-end deep learning. Our architecture is significantly simpler than traditional speech systems, which rely on laboriously engineered processing pipelines; these traditional systems also tend to perform poorly when used in noisy environments. In contrast, our system does not need hand-designed components to model background noise, reverberation, or speaker variation, but instead directly learns a function that is robust to such effects. We do not need a phoneme dictionary, nor even the concept of a "phoneme." Key to our approach is a well-optimized RNN training system that uses multiple GPUs, as well as a set of novel data synthesis techniques that allow us to efficiently obtain a large amount of varied data for training. Our system, called Deep Speech, outperforms previously published results on the widely studied Switchboard Hub5'00, achieving 16.0% error on the full test set. Deep Speech also handles challenging noisy environments better than widely used, state-of-the-art commercial speech systems.Collapse
output: The method used in the research is described in the abstract as "a state-of-the-art speech recognition system developed using end-to-end deep learning." The key aspect of the method is that it is based on end-to-end deep learning, which allows the system to learn a function that is robust to background noise, reverberation, and speaker variation without needing hand-designed components. The system also does not need a phoneme dictionary or the concept of phonemes. The training system is optimized for performance and uses multiple GPUs, and the data synthesis techniques allow for efficient acquisition of varied training data.

instruction: Provide an ESRB rating for the following game.
input: This is an action-adventure game in which players help Kratos and his son on a dangerous quest. Players explore various realms and engage in frenetic hand-to-hand combat against human-like raiders and fantastical creatures (e.g., centaurs, trolls, dragons). Players use axes and chained blades to battle enemies, often resulting in large blood-splatter effects and dismemberment. Players can perform finishing attacks that depict close-up impalement via bladed and hand-held weapons; repeated axe strikes to a creature's neck results in decapitation. The words “f**k” and “sh*t” are heard in the game.
